rotwelsch just pointed out where the problem lies, at least in my opinion. i have had a brief look at this, but i the only thing i can add for the moment are the following following two links describing the problem:
http://svn.apache.org/repos/asf/subversion/trunk/notes/unicode-composition-for-filenames
https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/qa/qa1235/_index.html
it boils down to the point that macosx gives back a stored filename/path decomposed, while windows and linux give back the path as it came: decomposed, composed or mixed. at this point things run out of order. apple recommends to use their api for handling of this point, because then the path is returned correctly.
this is the starting point as far as i can see it.

the client deals with the problem by converting filenames whenever it accesses the filesystem. internally (and over the wire, i.e. in urls as mandated by rfc3987), it's converted to nfc. what needs to be clarified is that only one representation is valid for a given os (either nfc or nfd), and that the server does the proper conversion.

caveat: this is (not) limited to the os the server is running on, depending on which remote backend is used.
